Transcription for 493253

This is William Morris Jones talking again about Barry docks.
Were you going to tell me something about pilfering?
In the war time, I personally didn't have any personal recollection of it.
But I guess what I was told by my father, that the problem there, it wasn't only true of Barry docks, it was true of all ports.
That the lifeboat emergency rations were plundered by people.
What sort of people?
The workers on the dock, dockside workers.
And this is what resulted if a ship that sank and a man had to go into the lifeboat.
They found there was no food in, no emergency rations.
Because it had been pilfered?
Because it had been pilfered.
And your father told you this?
Yes.
Did he take any action about it?
Well if they were caught, they would be severely punished.
Was there a detective force at the docks?
Not to my knowledge.
So it's just this lifeboat pilfering?
Yes, in the war time.
What sort of rations did they have?
Biscuits, hard rationed biscuits.
Biscuits and things that would keep.
And when they took these biscuits and things, did they keep them for themselves or sell them on?
I think they were sold on.
Oh I can tell you now, this again is in the war time.
I personally have no personal recollection of it.
There was an American army depot there.
In Barrie?
In Barrie, yes, a big one, a large one.
Do you recall the depot?
I can't remember, it was before I went to work there.
And it was full of all kinds of things for American...
Oh you mean the depot was at the docks?
The depot was at the docks, yes.
And this was plundered.
All kinds of things were taken from the American stores.
So they would have had things like chocolate?
That's right, yes.
This kind of thing, chocolates and sweets and all kinds of things.
The American troops were lavishly supplied with all kinds of things, sweets and all kinds of things.
And this was when your father was working there?
Yes.
So he would have had first hand knowledge of it?
Oh yes, yes.
And he was the secretary you said?
He ended up as the secretary, yes.
During the war what did he do there?
Well, he was in a reserved occupation so he wasn't called up.
He was, I would say, an under manager.
Right.
And he was also a home guard captain.
Oh.
So as an under manager he would have had to manage the men?
Yes.
No, not directly, no.
He would be involved with office work.
There were foremen and someone who directly managed the men.
Right.
Yes.
Excellent.
Well thank you very much.
If I can think of something else.
Right, let me know and I'll come and record it.
I'll try to think of something else, no.
Oh, what about Howard?
Howard...
Howard Reese.
Howard Reese.
Yes.
When did he become a policeman?
He became a policeman, yes.
When?
After the war.
Oh, right.
Yes, nothing to do with the docks.
Right, thank you.
His brother did.
His brother Peter, he worked in the office.
At the docks?
Yes.
He became a pilot and was killed in an air crash after the war.
Oh dear.
Yes.
What did Peter Reese do at the docks?
He was in the office, office clerk.
With your father then?
Yes.
Oh, right.
Did your father get him the job?
Yes.
Oh, very good.
Thank you.
Oh, there was also flour mills.
Flour mills?
They imported wheat.
From Canada?
From Canada, yes.
All my father's brother worked there.
Right, thank you.
Well, I'll come and record it.
Yes.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
